fr:mainmatter.html:p: We aim to show that every regular language is automatical. The rule induction principle for regular expressions implies that the regular languages are the smallest class of formal languages closed under unions, concatenation, repetition, single symbols, the empty string, and the empty language. Therefore, to prove our desired theorem it will suffice to show that the automatical languages are closed under the same constructions.

fr:title.text: The closure condition denoted by a syntactic rule

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: The closure condition denoted by a syntactic rule

fr:mainmatter.html:p: When \mathcal {R} is a set of rules over X, we will write \mathrm {Cl}_{\mathcal {R}}\subseteq \mathcal {P}{\mathopen {}\left (X\right )\mathclose {}} for the intersection of the closure conditions denoted by each rule in \mathcal {R}. This is, in other words, the set of subsets of X that lie in the closure condition for each rule r\in \mathcal {R}.
The basic form of a rule that describes a subset of a set X is as follows:

The plain English meaning of the rule is: If u_1 through u_n are elements of the subset that I am defining, then so is v. In such a rule, the items on top of the horizontal line are called premises or antecedents or hypotheses, and the item on the bottom of the horizontal line is called the conclusion. When a rule has no premises, it is called an axiom.
